top_categories.workout_context: Transcontinental Race’s 3100-mile distance demands power production deep into fatigue — the defining challenge of ultra-distance gravel.

Transcontinental Race’s predominantly paved roads, mandatory gravel parcours, variable surfaces and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Every session at Transcontinental Race intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Racing Transcontinental Race isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Transcontinental Race’s paved roads, gravel parcours demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
At 3100 miles, Transcontinental Race rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Transcontinental Race when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Transcontinental Race’s 210,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Transcontinental Race rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Transcontinental Race — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.

Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Transcontinental Race — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on predominantly paved roads, mandatory gravel parcours, variable surfaces.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Transcontinental Race’s predominantly paved roads, mandatory gravel parcours, variable surfaces delivers on race day.

race_overlay.heat: July in Across Europe (route changes annually) — The TCR is 'two races in one.' Alpine sections can hit near-freezing with storms, sleet, and snow at high passes. Then the Balkans and Eastern Europe bring 40C+ heatwaves, brutal sun exposure, and zero shade. Riders must prepare for 0-40C temperature range within a single race. Flooding, thunderstorms, and heatwaves are all common. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Transcontinental Race — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day. Race-day realities: 40C+ Balkan heat.
race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 3100 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 3100 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.altitude: Transcontinental Race with 210,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Transcontinental Race requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on predominantly paved roads, mandatory gravel parcours, variable surfaces to build confidence. Expect: paved roads, gravel parcours, cobblestones.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, VO2max, and Endurance to prepare you for 3100 miles of predominantly paved roads, mandatory gravel parcours, variable surfaces in Across Europe (route changes annually).
